This is a perception throughout our community and, though the banks do not like to admit it, they are actively battling this every day.

There are some facts that support this public perception. The first of these is the substantial profits banks have made in the last few years. Last year alone the four big banks made a combined profit in excess of $9.4 billion for the financial year. The media continues to report these billion dollar profits made by the banks. What is causing anger in our community is not the profits themselves but the widespread belief that these profits have been made at the expense of and without regard to consumers' welfare. Bank closures fuel this anger. To give the House an idea of the scale of this problem, I will quote the following statement from an article by Patricia Howard in July's edition of Australian CPA:

quote.para: According to the Reserve Bank of Australia 2,060 branches have been closed across the country between July 1993 and July 2000, a cutback of 29 per cent of all bank branches. For the banks it is a simple accounting decision, but for the thousands of Australians who suddenly find they can no longer access even the most basic financial services in their local area the effect can be devastating.

speech.para: This article highlights the enormous social costs of bank closures in rural and regional Australia. But people in metropolitan areas are also feeling the pain of bank closures. In metropolitan areas it is the poor, the disabled and the aged who are disadvantaged, while in rural and regional areas it is the whole community that is affected. A simple illustration of the rate of bank closures in this country is that five branches a week have closed over the last seven years—one every working day. Every weekday a bank branch closes in this country—unbelievable but true.

What can government do? Labor believes that banking is an essential service and banks do have social obligations that are broader than for other commercial organisations. The licensing of banks imposes responsibilities as well as privileges which go beyond just being good corporate citizens. An essential plank of Labor's policy is a social charter of community obligations for banks. Through a process of consultation with industry and community groups Labor will negotiate a social charter of community obligations for banks. The social charter will be legally binding on the banks, like a contract. If the banks refuse to negotiate an acceptable charter, then a Labor government will impose a social charter through legislation. Labor wants the social charter for the banks to include the following items: a basic bank account which enables fee-free banking for social security recipients, a no-frills bank account offering minimal bank fees for all Australians and a number of other measures. These items are not unreasonable. They are the basic building blocks of a fair and equitable banking system.

Labor recognises that the Australian public has had enough of being taken for granted. It is now time for the banks to fulfil their social responsibilities voluntarily or to be forced to do so by legislation. The Howard government has not done enough to stop the erosion of retail banking services in this country. I hope to stand in this House next year and not have to complain about the further erosion of banking services again. I hope to stand in this House and talk about the success of the social charter of community obligations for the banks. Only a Beazley Labor government can deliver this. (Time expired)

talk.start.para: —About three or four weeks ago, in a blaze of publicity, the New South Wales State Education Minister, John Aquilina, announced some $567,000 in funding for a skill centre to be built at the Woy Woy High School. This was a sweetener to the parents and students involved in the merger of two schools, Umina High School and Woy Woy High School. Obviously there has been a great deal of concern in the community about the merger of those two schools. In this great blaze of publicity John Aquilina said, `We will give you the skill centre down at Woy Woy High School for the senior part of the school to access and give you IT training, service and business skills.' What Mr Aquilina forgot to tell the parents, and the rest of the community, was that the $567,000 was not state government money. It was not new money. It was $567,000 of Commonwealth funding—and not one dollar of state government funding—which had already been allocated to a skill centre which was to be located in Donnison Street in Gosford in a one-stop shop youth facility. It had already been funded with $220,000 under the ACC RAP funding. The state government was contributing to that as well. This facility was to allow all high schools on the Central Coast to access it. I have a list of them: high schools at Berkeley Vale, Erina, Kincumber, Lisarow, Narara Valley, Terrigal, The Entrance, Tumbi Umbi, Umina, Woy Woy, Wyong and Green Point, and Henry Kendall High School, St Peters, St Edwards, St Josephs and Central Coast grammar. Mr Aquilina has not told the parents of Umina high or Woy Woy high whether those 1,470 other students are still going to be able to access that centre or whether it is only for the students of Woy Woy high.

speech.para: There are a lot of questions which need to be asked of Minister Aquilina on what is happening. The fact that they have withdrawn $567,000 from this important youth centre in the centre of Gosford—where every student could access these facilities—now jeopardises the whole viability of this project. The Commonwealth had already contributed $220,000. Only three weeks ago the Special Minister of State, who is also the minister for the Central Coast and minister for many other things in the state government, John Della Bosca, came up to the youth facility in Donnison Street to a great fanfare. We had a lovely function there with the media present. He presented a cheque from the state government for $250,000. He was not even aware that his own state government member John Aquilina had ripped out $567,000 of Commonwealth funding proposed for this facility. The state government have been up there grandstanding saying, `We are giving you $250,000'. But secretly they have ripped out $567,000 of Commonwealth funding to give it to Woy Woy High School and have made a big song and dance about all this extra funding from the state government to the school. That is not the truth. This is not what the parents are being told at public meetings. We need to continue to ask questions of John Aquilina.

There is no doubt that there is a need for a facility down at the combined high schools of Woy Woy and Umina. I have no problems with having a skill facility there to enable students to make the transition from school to work, but the facility should be funded by the state government. They are state government schools. This just shows the sneakiness of the state government in claiming all the time that the Commonwealth is not contributing to state government facilities and schools. Here is a classic example of the deceit of the New South Wales Carr government in the way that they secretly snuck this money out of this very important facility, rebadged it and claimed it as their own. They made a big song and dance about how wonderful they are. In fact, they have not added one extra dollar.

This is another example of how the state governments have claimed that the Commonwealth government is not contributing to state school funding. The Commonwealth's spending on government schools is at the highest level ever. All states and territories have received funding increases for government schools every year since this government came in during 1996. The total funding for government schools in the 2002 budget is estimated to be $2.2 billion. Over the 2001-04 quadrennium it will total over $9 billion. In 2002 Commonwealth spending will increase by 43 per cent. (Time expired)

talk.start.para: —I was very proud to be elected to the House of Representatives on 2 March 1996. I have not been too proud of this parliament in the last week. At the end of the day, the issues we are debating come down to race and religion, and I believe the debate diminishes us as a parliament and as a nation. It was one thing to have Pauline Hanson as an Independent sprouting words and pressing reactionary buttons in the community. It is another thing to have a government and a Prime Minister that are prepared to do that as well. I would rather lose my seat than engage in the sort of divisive conduct that we have seen from this Prime Minister.

speech.para: Last night a bill was presented to the parliament, a bill for which no notice was given to the opposition, a bill for which there was no explanatory memorandum; a bill which sought to override decades of laws in this nation without any public or community debate. That bill would have overridden all other laws without qualification, including international maritime laws and Australian criminal and civil laws. It allowed unreviewable, absolute discretion for Australian officials in removing vessels from Australian territorial waters without giving any consideration whatsoever to whether those vessels are seaworthy or any consideration whatsoever to the health and safety of people who may be on board. It provided no guidance as to when, how or why a decision on a vessel would be made. It provided no definition of `reasonable means' or `reasonable force'. It was so broad that it would allow the exclusion of Australian citizens on Australian vessels without any avenue of parliamentary or judicial challenge or review.

As the leader of the Labor Party said last night and on AM this morning in opposing this bill, we need `cool heads and generous hearts'. I am firmly of the view that we do need leadership, and leadership is not about responding to every poll. Leadership is about doing what is right.

talk.start.para: —Leadership is about humanity, caring for people and being prepared to take a stand, as the leader of the Labor Party has done in opposing this bill. This is not a refugee crisis—400 people on a boat do not represent a crisis. This is a political crisis for us as a nation, which has been brought on by a desperate Prime Minister.

speech.para: Unfortunately members of the Liberal Party are interjecting during my speech. At their caucus meeting this week, the new member for Aston suggested that we drop bombs either side of boats as they approach Australian territory. That is the level of debate that has been brought on by the conservative parties. In his speech in the parliament, the Prime Minister referred to Australia's response to the Indo-Chinese crisis. Well, Prime Minister, you are no Malcolm Fraser! This was a nation in which we had bipartisan support for tolerance and compassion on these sorts of issues. What we need is a comprehensive solution, and the government's legislation would not provide that. You can push this boat out to sea but, unless it has somewhere to go, what will happen? The problem will remain. And does it become a yoyo: going out to sea and back again, going out to sea and back again? This is an issue that requires a comprehensive solution based upon the law and based upon decent humanity. (Time expired)

talk.start.para: —In the Kimberley region of my electorate is the township of Broome, an area that many Australians would recognise for its tourist appeal generally and for its world renowned South Sea pearls in particular. Broome is one of the fastest growing communities in the vast Kalgoorlie electorate. The greatest encumbrance on the continuity of that growth is its wharf facilities. Infrastructure, while satisfactory at the time of building, can quickly become inadequate when trying to cope with rapid growth. That is the case in Broome, where the Broome wharf, managed by the Broome Port Authority, is in dire need of expansion to cater for the growth in the shipping industry, particularly that related to oil and gas exploration ventures.

speech.para: The berthing space at the wharf is unchanged since the jetty was completed in 1966, even though the number of vessels of all types calling at the wharf has increased from 15 to a maximum of 190 a month over the period. In addition to the obvious restrictions of lack of berthing space, there is major inconvenience and restriction whenever a petroleum tanker is discharging. The 25-metre exclusion zone around the 183-metre long Australian Pride encompasses the entire wharf, resulting in the need to close the wharf to all other traffic whenever the tanker is discharging. The port has to be closed because of this about eight times a year, for periods of between 36 hours and four days. This is unacceptable for a region that is thriving, growing and contributing substantially to the regional and national economy.

The Broome Port Authority has plans to almost double the length of the wharf by constructing a 148-metre extension. The cost of this extension is estimated to be $14 million. The port authority is seeking funding from both the federal government and the Western Australian state government, in addition to raising capital itself. The port authority is seeking $5.5 million in federal funding for this expansion. This request for funding is one that I strongly support and urge this government to support. Every encouragement should be given to expansion of this infrastructure to service the growing regional economy, much of which is maritime dependent, in the West Kimberley.

The prospective growth in this region is phenomenal. There was $42 million in live beef exports through the Broome port last year. Numbers of cattle exported annually have grown from 30,000 in 1997-98 to over 80,000 a head in 2000-01. Whilst dominated by pearling, the fishing industry in Broome also includes fin fish and prawning. The fishing industry in the region is serviced solely by the port of Broome. The number of visits from luxury cruise ships is also increasing, with Broome rapidly being recognised as a new and exotic destination for the world's cruise shipping companies. There have been at least seven visits to the port during the last couple of years by luxury cruise liners, and the port has had an inquiry from the cruise liner QEII to call at Broome. This vessel is 110 metres longer than the deepwater berth at the port. There has also been proven growth in the oil and gas exploration industry using the port, and the port authority aims to secure the business of all offshore exploration in the port's 1,000-kilometre long catchment area—midway between the distant offshore service bases of Dampier and Darwin. In addition to industry use, the berthing space is rapidly becoming inadequate to service the growing needs of customers, including the Royal Australian Navy, Customs and Immigration.

Extension to the wharf could be completed within 18 months of obtaining approval for project funding, and the benefits are substantial. Benefits would include an enhanced ability for strategic deployment by naval and customs vessels, something that is immensely topical at this time; an ability to cater for and service vessels whilst a tanker is alongside; increased berthing space; cost-efficient oil and gas exploration; a reduction in waiting time for berths; and a boost to maritime dependent industries in the Kimberley. I believe adequate port facilities are vital to ensure the sustained growth of industry in the Kimberley region, and I urge the government to show its support by way of financial assistance.

talk.start.para: —Mr Deputy Speaker, this is a government without honour or sense. This is a government that introduced last night one of the most draconian pieces of legislation that any parliament or any assembly in the world could have envisaged in the darkest days that those countries may have had. The Border Protection Bill 2001 is not merely draconian but it is senseless. Our legal position, based on our current legislation and on our current understandings with our treaty partners worldwide as well as on our understanding of what international maritime law is, covers our situation with regard to the vessel that is currently off Christmas Island. What we did not need is a bill which is directed towards the re-election of the coalition government on the basis of generating a crisis and continuing it and trying to profit from that crisis electorally.

speech.para: We have a situation where a bill was introduced into the parliament without notice—except for probably the shortest of notices, 40 minutes or so, to the Leader of the Opposition—and that was deliberately done in order to push a certain point of view. I say it is without honour and without sense for two reasons. First, the current situation that we find ourselves in in relation to this vessel and the people who are on it is only part of the broad fabric of what has happened in the last 5½ years in regard to the refugee problem. We have had over 11,000 people enter Australia during that period. In the 13 years that we were in office we had about 3,000 people enter in the same sort of way. Before I was in this place, working in the previous job I had, I spent more than 11 years ensuring that our border protection and control was as strong and vigorous and tough as we could possibly make it.

It is important, no matter who is in government, that we actually control our borders, that we determine what our immigration policy is and that we determine how Australia responds to crises. It has not helped us at all—this is where this government is completely without sense—not to deal with the other countries in the region with a view to staunching this at the point where it started.

We have professional people smugglers being paid money to bring people to Australia in large numbers. We have had that situation previously. Whilst we were in government we had that situation with people from southern China, from the Hunan province—not just a couple of people, not just dozens of people, not just hundreds of people, but thousands. The way to fix the problem finally, instead of just having truck loads, boat loads or plane loads of people landing on these shores and then having to be dealt with by our processes at hand, is to actually negotiate with those other countries involved—in our case with China—to seek a local solution to the cause of the problem. We do not have many people coming from that province now. Why? Because the Australian government and the Australian department of immigration put the time, the effort, the thought and the sense into solving the problem at its point of initiation.

Here we have a clear problem that we need to talk about to Indonesia, which is providing a way of passage for people flying into Indonesia and then on to Australia. We need to talk to them seriously, not just about this current issue but about the whole issue of how we deal with the wider problem of people smuggling into Australia. We cannot protect our borders unless we do it in an extended way with every other country in the region.

I note with pleasure, from talking to the ABC, that the ABC will be bringing back an Australian television coverage into the Asia-Pacific region—and not before time. This is coverage that was slashed by this government. We need an independent presence for Australia in the region, and at no time more than now so that we can restore an honoured position, and a sensible and logical position, to Australia's approach to these problems. (Time expired)

talk.start.para: —Mr Deputy Speaker, there are some things that you know are certain in life and some that you do not. I happen to know that today is certain to be the last occasion on which I will have the privilege of standing in this adjournment debate in the Main Committee because of things that are about to happen to me with regard to my future. It is an opportunity for me to record my deep appreciation to you, to the Speaker and to all the officers of the parliament—the clerks, the advisers, the attendants and the wonderful people who help us to do our difficult job and keep us out of strife, as they often do with great dignity and integrity and, of course, always with absolute independence and even-handedness. That has been a great thing that I have observed over the 25 years that I have been in state and federal parliaments: the hidden strengths of our parliamentary system.

speech.para: I would just like to make a couple of comments. I have not got all the answers by far, but I have been listening very closely to some Labor speakers this morning on the Border Protection Bill. I have watched the Leader of the Opposition, the person who aspires to be Australia's next Prime Minister, and I have watched my Prime Minister very closely over the last little while. I heard the Leader of the Opposition say that he supported the government's actions up to yesterday. The Prime Minister was obviously getting an endorsement as, in a Westminster system, in serious times you do come together.

I am puzzled, though, because suddenly the people on the government side—and I am one of them, and proud to be—are being accused by some Labor members of being racist, and that is just not on. It is not on, it is not fair and it is not consistent because what you are saying is that most of the things we are doing—you might not agree on some, but the core of what we are doing—are for Australia's sovereignty. This is something that needs to be done and has to be done. It is not easy and it is not pleasant, but it has to be done. How come the Leader of the Opposition can take the same stance that we have been taking—until he did last night depart somewhat—while we are branded by his colleagues as being racists? It is inconsistent in that you are actually in a way indirectly branding your own leader as a racist, because the core principles and values we have spoken about in this place on this issue are, I think, bipartisan. So it is really quite strange.

The second thing I would like to say, in a friendly gesture, is that you have the right in a democracy to put your view on legislation and, of course, you should do it robustly and with courage. There are no problems with that. I am not offended by you doing it, except when you label good hardworking colleagues in the parliament on both sides unfairly and turn the debate into one about racism, which is quite wrong and unfair. My understanding of international law and maritime law—and I am not an expert on it—is that all countries have a sovereign right to protect their waters and their borders. They have a right to say to someone who comes in without authority and without our approval, `Go; remove yourself.' That is unarguable. That is the law. Furthermore, countries in the world have a right to use reasonable means to ensure that their order is obeyed.

If you do not have that inherent right, which is what the legislation the Prime Minister brought in enunciates in codified form, what are you arguing? Is it that the sovereign right of a nation does not exist to enforce a decision? That is really intellectually the issue, and I have not heard anything about it. I would like to see what you say about what steps you would take to protect your sovereign rights. I really would. If you want to codify the law, tell us what you say the law should say about how you can enforce the rights.

Time is nearly upon me. I just want to say one thing: if ever this nation needed four-year parliaments, it needs them now. I have observed the fact that we do not get enough things done because of the short cycle of elections, and I hope that we will amend the Constitution very quickly to allow for four-year parliaments. Thank you for all your courtesy and for your friendship towards me. I wish you all well.

debate.para: The following answers to questions were circulated:

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Health and Aged Care, upon notice, on 27 February 2001:

quote.para: (1) Does he recognise that hormone replacement therapy (HRT) can provide significant medical benefits for women who (a) require relief for the symptoms of menopause, (b) have undergone partial or complete hysterectomies and (c) are at risk of, and/or suffering from osteoporosis.
(2) Does he acknowledge that due to negative side effects many women who have had a hysterectomy are unable to take alternative forms of hormone replacement therapy such as Estraderm or Premarin.
(3) Is he aware that oestrogen implants are not available on the Pharmaceutical Benefits Scheme (PBS).
(4) Why are women ineligible for oestrogen implants under the PBS whilst under certain circumstances, men are eligible for testosterone implants under the PBS.
(5) Will he consider the inclusion of oestrogen implants for PBS listing.

talker.name: Wooldridge, Dr Michael, MP
Dr Wooldridge
talker.role: Minister for Health and Aged Care

talk.start.para: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

quote.para: (1) (a) HRT can provide significant benefits in terms of symptom relief for women suffering from both natural and surgically induced menopause. The benefits may include reduction in hot flushes and sweating, improvement in urinary symptoms, improved mood and reduction in sleep disturbance;
(b) Women who have undergone partial or complete hysterectomies can benefit from HRT providing they are menopausal; and

(c) There is also good evidence to show that HRT has a protective effect against bone mass loss and thus may be an aid in the prevention of osteoporosis. There is some evidence to suggest that in women who have developed osteoporosis, HRT will increase bone mass density.

(2) Negative side effects are formulation specific and whether a woman has had a hysterectomy or not, or has undergone natural or surgically induced menopause is not considered to have a bearing on their tolerance to treatment. Generally, the choice of oestrogen dosage form by a prescribing doctor will depend on a number of factors, including the indication for treatment, the risks associated with the particular condition and side effects experienced by an individual patient. A variety of oestrogen dosage forms such as oral tablets, transdermal patches, vaginal creams and pessaries, and implants are on the Australian Register of Therapeutic Goods, to meet the various needs of patients.

However, there is a high, long term risk of osteoporosis in patients who have undergone surgical menopause and therefore, it is necessary to ensure long term treatment and compliance with HRT, often at higher doses. In this group of patients intolerance to oestrogen may pose a significant clinical dilemma. The focus in these cases would be toward a multidisciplinary approach that includes, weight-bearing exercise, cessation of smoking, reduction in alcohol use, diet and calcium supplementation.
(3) Yes

(4) Before a medicine can be subsidised via the PBS, it must be both recommended for listing by the Pharmaceutical Benefits Advisory Committee (PBAC) and a suitable price for listing agreed with the Pharmaceutical Benefits Pricing Authority.

At its September 1996 meeting, the PBAC recommended that oestrogen implants be listed as pharmaceutical benefits for postmenopausal symptoms and where oral oestrogens are not tolerated. However, negotiations between the Government and the pharmaceutical company for a mutually acceptable price have not been successful and consequently listing has not eventuated.

In the case of testosterone implants, listing on the PBS was implemented on 1 November 1996 following a positive recommendation from the PBAC and the successful completion of price negotiations with the manufacturer.

(5) In order to progress the PBAC recommendation, there must be a satisfactory outcome on price; the Government hopes that negotiations will continue, with a view to agreeing a price which allows the listing of oestrogen implants on a basis which is cost effective.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Community Services, upon notice, on 6 August 2001:

quote.para: (1) How many individuals in Australia were sent letters signed by him informing them about the Pension Bonus Scheme.
(2) How many individuals in the electoral division of Prospect were sent these letters.
(3) What criteria were used to select each individual.
(4) Were local Centrelink offices advised that the letters were being sent.
(5) Was information provided by the Australian Taxation Office to him about each individual; if so, what information was provided.
(6) Was Centrelink excluded from the process; if so, why.
(7) What has been the overall response to his mail out.

talker.name: Anthony, Larry, MP
Mr Anthony
talker.role: Minister for Community Services

talk.start.para: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

quote.para: (2) That data is not available.

(3) People over Age Pension age (who were not on Age Pension) or registered for the Pension Bonus Scheme with Centrelink, and people within 5 years of pension age who declared income from employment or self-employment and primary production in their 1999/2000 tax return.
(4) All Centrelink local offices were advised about the mailout and its contents.
(7) There has been a marked increase in the number of people registering in the scheme since the mailout.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Justice and Customs, upon notice, on 6 August 2001:

quote.para: (1) When was the $400 duty free allowance introduced.
(2) Has consideration been given to increasing the allowance since then.
(3) Is a review process in place to monitor the level of the duty free allowance; if so, what is the extent and nature of the review process.
(4) Was consideration given to reviewing the duty free allowance at the time the GST was introduced.
(5) What sum of GST revenue has been generated as a result of the imposition of the GST on goods on which customs duty has been paid.

talker.name: Williams, Daryl, MP
Mr Williams
talker.role: Attorney-General

talk.start.para: —The Minister for Justice and Customs has provided the following answer to the honourable member's question:

quote.para: (1) The $400 duty free allowance was introduced in 1987.

(2) Yes. In 1994 an inter-departmental committee (IDC) considered submissions from industry and subsequently recommended that there should be no change to the $400 limit. An IDC to review passenger and crew concessions was also convened this year and is currently reviewing the allowance as part of that process.

(3) Yes. The level of duty free allowances is reviewed periodically by relevant Government agencies in consultation with industry bodies. Submissions are considered by an IDC. Its recommendations are considered by the Heads of the departments involved and submitted to relevant Ministers (through me as Minister for Justice and Customs) for their approval.

Any changes to concessions require amendments to Customs by-laws issued to item 15 in Schedule 4 to the Customs Tariff and to the Incoming Passenger Card (owned and printed by the Department of Immigration and Multicultural Affairs) as well as a range of Customs publications.
(4) No. It was considered more appropriate to conduct a review once the effects of the GST could be better assessed.
(5) The total amount of GST revenue collected from incoming passengers in respect of goods not covered by the $400 passenger concession between 1 July 2000 and 12 August 2001 was $237,833.31.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Community Services, upon notice, on 6 August 2001:

quote.para: Can the Minister guarantee that payments of the $300 one-off bonus announced in the 2001 Budget to eligible residents of aged care facilities were paid directly to, and received separately by, those residents and not the management of the aged care facilities in which they reside; if not, why not.

talker.name: Anthony, Larry, MP
Mr Anthony
talker.role: Minister for Community Services

talk.start.para: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

quote.para: The $300 one-off payment was forwarded to eligible people with their pension payments in June 2001.

The $300 one-off payment is not part of the Age Pension, and so it is not counted in calculating daily care fees for residents in aged care homes. Centrelink explained these arrangements in a letter dated 20 June 2001 to all nursing home proprietors.

Some residents have chosen to have their pensions directed to the aged care home, and in these cases, the aged care home deducts the resident's care fee and pays the balance to the individual. Where there is an additional payment such as the $300 one-off payment, the full amount of the one-off payment is paid, either by cheque, cash or into the resident's own trust account, for their own use.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Community Services, upon notice, on 7 August 2001:

quote.para: (1) Has his attention been drawn to an apparent unfairness in the Child Support Scheme where, following a marriage breakdown, the female payer left the marital home and her husband and three young children, subsequently took out a bank loan and studied in order to secure employment, obtained a good job, and has now been advised that she had incurred a debt of $6,134.08, plus interest, due to her salary packaging.
(2) What measures are in place to allow payers who pursue further education to support themselves and advance their careers, to not be subjected to paying ever-increasing child support payments.

talker.name: Anthony, Larry, MP
Mr Anthony
talker.role: Minister for Community Services

talk.start.para: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

quote.para: (1) Parliament decided in 1988 that parents should financially support their children, according to their capacity to pay. Child support is calculated on the basis of a parent's capacity to financially support their children as they would have had they not separated. If a paying parent is receiving some benefit from salary packaging that is not reflected by their taxable income, then it is appropriate that this be considered in determining the amount of child support payable.

(2) The Child Support Scheme is based on the principle that parents have a primary duty to financially support their children and that children have a right to share in the changing financial circumstances of their parents. If a paying parent chooses to pursue further education, their individual circumstances can be considered in the assessment of an appropriate child support liability. Where this leads to career advancement, it is appropriate that the child support assessment reflect the parent's increased capacity to pay.

subdebateinfo.title: Australian Defence Force Explosive Ordnance Storage, Maintenance and Distribution Project
subdebateinfo.subtitle: (Question No. 2860)

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Defence, upon notice, on 9 August 2001:

quote.para: (1) Which firms actually submitted bids for the ADF Explosive Ordnance Storage Maintenance and Distribution Project.
(2) Did Complete Ammunition Services submit an in-house bid in conjunction with their commercial sector sub-contractors Brown & Root, J D Edwards, Wesfarmers and Skilled Engineering.
(3) Was the in-house bid the lowest cost compliant bid for the contract.

(4) On what basis was the in-house bid, submitted on behalf of experienced staff involved in providing explosive ordnance storage and distribution for the ADF, rated as compliant but inferior to all other bidders in terms of their ability to conduct the business.
(5) What was the difference in the indicative tender price submitted by the in-house bid compared to that submitted by the successful bidder, ADI Ltd.
(6) Did the in-house bid fail to comply with any of the tender requirements; if so, which specific requirements did it fail to meet.
(7) Was the in-house bid rated as presenting minimal risk to Defence.
(8) On what specific grounds was the ADI proposal considered to provide better value for money than the less expensive bid submitted by the existing in-house team.

talker.name: Reith, Peter, MP
Mr Reith
talker.role: Minister for Defence

talk.start.para: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

quote.para: (1) Bids were received from:
(a) ADI Limited (ADI).
(b) Australian Defence Logistics Pty Ltd, a joint venture company between TNT Australia Pty Ltd and Transfield Pty Ltd.
(c) British Aerospace Australia Limited.
(d) Complete Ammunition Services, the (In-House Option).
(e) Force Logistics Pty Ltd, a joint undertaking between Serco Australia Pty Ltd and Mayne Nickless Limited.
(2) Yes.

(3) The in-house option submitted the lowest price bid. There was some doubt as to whether the in-house option was compliant but the issue did not need to be resolved because the in-house option was not chosen as the Preferred Tenderer. Financial investigation showed that significant costs had not been included or were understated by the in-house option and there was substantial risk of cost escalation.

(4) A rigorous tender evaluation by an experienced team was conducted against published evaluation criteria. Each response was assessed fairly against each criteria for technical merit and risk. The in-house option was favourably assessed but in a strong field did not represent best value for money for the Commonwealth. The in-house option team has been briefed in detail on the reasons why it was not successful.

(5) The ranking of tenders is based on value for money not price. The price submitted by the in-house bid was less than that of the Preferred Tenderer. The lower price from the in-house bid was questionable and assessed as an underbid over the life of the contract. The in-house bid claimed that it did not need to comply with the price variation formula and that cost increases in labour and materiel would be passed on to the Commonwealth. In summary, the evaluation team had a low level of confidence in the in-house bid price. ADI's bid was assessed as providing best value for money. The in-house team has been fully debriefed - including a comparison of their price and the successful bid price.

(6) For technical merit, tenderers were assessed on a ten point scale against compliance and performance. No tenderer received a score of less than 5 which indicated “meets the requirement, but with some shortcomings”. The Preferred Tenderer received significantly higher assessments than the in-house option and was selected on an overall assessment of “value for money”.
(7) The in-house option was assessed as presenting low risk in the provision of explosive ordnance support, but a higher risk in staffing and price levels.

(8) The Preferred Tenderer was assessed as presenting very low risk in the provision of explosive ordnance support. The Preferred Tenderer's technical solution was considered to provide better value for money. The assessment was based on an aggregate consideration of all issues rather than one or two specific issues.
